content.body: ...what the hell?
What the hell what?
Your bizarro train-of-thought spew.
Bizarro?
It is a very good idea.
And something I've wanted for ages.
Is there a REQUEST-PONY header in HTTP 2.0?
Why are you making fun of this?
Do you have any idea how this would revolutionize the Internet?
is "Windows 95 style commercial jippo" not a humorous reference?
I meant that it would be big-scale.
Something that everyone hears about.
or "all major browsers coming out within a week with full support for"
(which has never happened on any spec/feature AFAIK)
Yes, "very soon".
or "super-safe payments" (what does that mean?)
Maybe they have had some kind of secret board meeting and agreed on this and worked behind the scenes.
The point is that it would be truly global, instant, no hazzles and one-click.
or "totally free from transaction fees" is that a wish? or a requirement in a standard? or an expected market outcome?
Or the transaction fee would have to be truly in %, so if the payment is $0.1, the fee truly is just a fraction of that. No minimum charges.
This would open so many doors.
sounds like you're asking for some kind of micropayment standard
searching for that...
I would sure as hell pay $0.1 to support a nice game or article, but I would not bother today to send that amount.
No... I mean that it should be right into the HTTP protocol, thus in the native browser UI.
the HTTP protocol is a standard
and $0.1 would be a micropayment
so I repeat, sounds like you're asking for some kind of micropayment standard
looking up micropayment...
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micropayment#History
looks like there is bad news

"During the late 1990s, there was a movement to create microtransaction standards,[5] and the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) worked on incorporating micropayments into HTML even going as far as to suggest the embedding of payment-request information in HTTP error codes.[4] The W3C has since stopped its efforts in this area,[4]"

If you'd like to propose a micropayment standard e.g. as an extension of HTTP, perhaps consider attempting to start a W3C Community Group on "HTTP micropayments" and see if you can get other people involved: http://www.w3.org/community/
I can't propose anything. It will have to come from the big boys who people listen to.
That they have not sat down in a conference room years ago is a mystery.
There must be some kind of evil conspiracy requiring them to not make it easy for people to pay and charge.
most successful standards start from individuals with good ideas, not "big boys"
from the Wikipedia article, sounds like they did discuss it (whether in a conference room or not is unknown) and eventually stopped efforts.
no evil conspiracy is required for inaction. that's simply inertia.

anyway, if you want to make it happen, try starting a community group to see if there is interest from others. if no one else is interested, then it means it's not worth creating a standard for it. if there are others interested, then you have to do the hard work of figuring out how it would work.
It's obvious that it's needed.

Not necessarily.  Micropayments have been attempted in lots of forms, both online and off.  They don't work very well.  Human psychology makes a huge deal of the difference between "free" and "not free", even if the "not free" is "so cheap it's practically free".
So, asking someone to pay 1 cent is psychologically equivalent to asking them to pay a few bucks, in terms of how willing the average person is willing to do it.
This might be changeable - it's not clear if this is something built into our psyche, or if it's a result of microtransactions never really being viable in the real world before the last few decades.
But resistance will be high regardless.

(There were simple experiments with real-world things, like giving people a choice between a 15c truffle and a 1c hershey kiss - 3/4 chose the truffle.  But if you drop the kiss to free, 2/3 choose it instead. Most people's brains break when they see "free".)
TabAtkins - the positive examples are music downloads (iTunes, Amazon) for < $1, and ringtones as well
as well as all those things people buy on Zynga games Farmville etc.
so there is some psychological precedent for it
especially in the use-case mentioned of (HTML5) games
why should Zynga make (nearly?) all the online/web game micropayment $?
TabAtkins_: Well, the price example was just an example.
tantek: That's true.  We do have a lot more microtransactions in today's world.
But even paying $1 is ridiculous today. It's eaten up by fees and is not anywhere near instant or hazzle-free.
In fact, it's a nightmare of credit card info, codes, bank hardware dongles and fees.
Or paying $10.
smokeyrat, Apple, Amazon, Zynga and others have figured out how to make < $1 payments work, perhaps you could research how they've done it and report back your results.
oh and please post your research on the web somewhere, preferably at a permalink with a creative commons / public domain license - that helps for work towards a standard
For them there isn't anything to figure out. It's a closed system with lots of users.
They enter cash and then they have some virtual credits to spend instantly.
Couldn't be simpler.
smokeyrat - perhaps you could write up your analysis in a blog post
You're thinking of Zynga.  Tantek also pointed out Apple and Amazon, which do microtransactions directly off your CC.
I was not aware that they do that. But that would require CC entering, etc.
So basically they store your CC info. Is that novel?
Storing CC information is trivial - browsers do that already for autocomplete.
That went well for Sony...
The difficulty appears to lay elsewhere.
TabAtkins_: well, browsers seem to attempt to *not* store CC info
(but that's a special case)
just realized that </figcaption> isn't an implied end tag. :/
should the xml:lang attribute be used in HTML5?
guzzlefry: no not in text/html documents
just use @lang
k, thanks
Does HTML5 have implicit end tags like older versions (pre-XHML)?
s/XHML/XHTML

do you guys know of some way to test a http client? I wrote one yesterday and what to check it against strange corner cases. connection losses, timeouts, shutdowns; broken ssl handshakes and unexpected re-negotiations. etc
daurnimator: I thought the HTTPbis WG had a test suite
MikeSmith: not much of one... and definiently not one that really tests the underlying tcp connection
I see
maybe could use some tests from browser projects
TabAtkins_: @import should maybe use the same rules as <link> when it comes to requiring text/css type and quirks mode
TabAtkins_: opera seems to use the same logic while chrome and firefox allow text/plain also in standards mode
TabAtkins_: hmm, chrome seems to allow text/html cross-origin @imports which i think is a security problem
in quirks mode

The internet is funny. CERN live streams a seminar intended for research scientists at which Higgs boson results are announced. Internet complains that a) research level particle physics is hard to follow and b) they used comic sans in the presentation
they wanted an apple keynote of the whole thing
are we confident that Higgs is smaller than pixels in retina display?
shwetank: I guess. Sadly the real world doesn't work like that
(also I feel great now I got to describe academica as "the real world")
moo-_-, that depends, how do you define the mass of a pixel in the retina display?
Lachy: Mass of screen divided by number of pixels?
do you include the mass of the glass covering it, or just the mass of the phosphorus material? Or you could define it as the energy emitted from the pixel when it's on.
var scrollTo = window.scrollTo;
w(scrollTo);
What should be logged?
Ohn interesting
Presumably it depends on whether var scrollTo creates a new global given that one already exists
on the window object
I, too, would presume that :)
looks for gsnedders

ObligatoryVenting: not being able to discern at on-hover whether a link opens a JavaScript window on top of your existing window, loads content in your current window, or if it opens a new window/tab.
So frustrating and unclear at times.
They used Comic Sans MS?!
Ms2ger: Yes, ultimate troll :)
What, me?
Thanks :)
The Comic Cans
Sans
Ultimate Science requires levity in the form of a funny font
Surely real science should be conveyed with a marker pen and transparency and OHP
Chalk, dammit
Using comic sans for presentations is a tradition that dates back for as long as people have been making computer-based slideshows
Though, the ultimate troll would be using Comic Sans MS in a LaTeX presentation
In an ideal world each slide is a couple of words plus a graph anyway
Nah, the ultimate troll was the guy that used 12pt Times New Roman
Nothing beats a graph with red-squiggly-underlined words that's clearly been screenshotted from Excel
annevk: Did you see the svg?
odinho: no missed it
Nothing beats a maintainer for those canvas tests...

omfg. some memory leak there!

Ms2ger: But then Fx came and owned us :-(

that looks like the Core-Doxcs t-shirt :)
Did I save over it :P
Zing
euh
Core-Docxs
minor announcement: http://annevankesteren.nl/2012/07/leaving-opera
annevk: http://odin.s0.no/tmp/Hodges_odinho-CORS-Diagram-SimpleRequest.svg Tada
my IRC client still displays the same picture funnily enough
Hm. Although I used Ubuntu font, so maybe I should use something neutral like arial if it messes up other places.
annevk: IRC client with pictures? Wat?
My lingogi shows the correct one now.
LimeChat shows images inline
including SVG
odinho: instead of .com it should prolly say .example or something
odinho: also GET lyrics.com/hello.txt is wrong
it's GET /hello.txt
Host: lyrics.com
thinks using a non-conventional TLD like ".example" would make the diagram harder to understand
annevk: It's not supposed to be real. It also misses the HTTP/1.1 stuff
I agree with Philip`
I'm just trying to make it easy for them newbies :P
But, lunch out in the sun!
(since "webapps.com" is clearly a domain name, but "webapps.example" isn't, so it'd have to be written like "http://webapps.example" to make it unambiguous but then it'd still look kind of weird)
won't anybody think of the children!!11
yeah but there are some unwritten rules against using actual domain names
annevk: Leaving Opera? What will you do?
smaug____: nothing much for now :)
oh
that is possibly a good choice
and after that, you'd be welcome to Mozilla ;)
annevk: does this change affect to your role as a spec editor?
smaug____: dunno, hope not too much, I like writing specs
annevk: http://www.w3.org/Consortium/Recruitment/#techeditor
MikeSmith: the link makes it sound interesting, but then there's "for HTML Working Group" on the actual page :)
what... " lead editor for the HTML Working Group"
the HTML WG is the new old HTML WG
annevk: trail of broken hearts behind you. First you leave the CSS WG, then the HTML WG, and now this
MikeSmith: quit while you're ahead?
heh
are you ahead?
annevk: leave them wanting more
dunno really, but soon I'm an unemployed bum and I like that idea
CSS WG was too much abuse, HTML WG was too much process abuse and irrelevant anyway given the WHATWG
I had no conflicts with Opera though, just felt like trying something else
WCSSTWG?
CSS WG was actually also mostly process nonsense, like how to divide WDs rather than how to solve problems
combined with a madman in charge that just gives problems
maybe the CSS WG would work better if it were more like the WebApps WG
WebApps WG seem to somehow be able to get stuff done without anybody trying to micro-manage it all and layer further process on it
anyway, question: Is there really no HTTP test suite anywhere?
IETF and testing? mwaha
is there a HTTP spec that doesn't suck?
jreschke has a couple of tests for some features though
zcorpan: rhetorical?
it seems whacky that IETF culture does not see any need for requiring test suites for RFCs
Why would you need tests? They're only requesting comments
heh
but don't browser projects have HTTP tests?
for RFCs it makes sense I guess, but not STDs
We should rename W3C specs RFTs
I would think Mozilla would at least have some HTTP tests
I expect everybody has some HTTP tests
Possibly not packaged as a suite
Mm
Or easy to reuse
And ours run JS on the server
So unless everyone wants to run a Gecko server... ;)
wonder if it's time to write an HTTP spec
annevk: Eh? Unemployed? How so?
MikeSmith: As an update to HTTP or merely a more concise up-to-date spec?
ashemedai: Oslo ran out of bacon cheeseburgers
ashemedai: as a real spec to document how it actually works
jgraham: Noooooes!
ashemedai: well you know, when you quit your job and there's no direct follow-up, that's what happens
MikeSmith: I can tell you that I know a bunch of folks who would be Real Happy(tm) if you do that.
MikeSmith: gsnedders worked on a part of that a long time ago
annevk: Ahh ok, it was a choice on your end. :)
MikeSmith: but never finished it unfortunately
interesting
I kind of vaguely remember that now
ashemedai: ah yeah, it was, and I'm welcome back ;)
annevk: Hehe, what kind of work do you want to do though?
Here's a thing
If I have a document with two framesets, is there a way to set an onload listener and tell *which* frameset loaded
jgraham: you mean two <frame>s?
Like <frameset rows="*" onload="something"><frameset></frameset>
I mean two framesets
You can nest framesets
sure, but they do not load anything
<frameset onload> reflects window.onload
right?
Oh wait
I am misunderstanding this test
zcorpan: right
I thought it was giving a load event on the frameset when all the subframes had loaded
But it isn't
Ignore me
Right, I now have a less confusing, non-racy test
annevk, so did you leave because Facebook is going to buy Opera? :)
Maybe facebook bought annevk
he left. surely that means something.
zcorpan: hehe

matjas, thanks
Ms2ger: I’ll leave a comment with some tests results in other browsers
Ms2ger: I think those rumors started after I quit
Aha!
the plot thickens? lol

isn't EvalError unused?

do any engines other than gecko have support for the opus audio codec yet?
hsivonen: MikeSmith: http://validator.keegan.st/

we should add this upstream
assertThrows(function(){ worker.port.onmessage = 1 }, [], TypeError, {});
zcorpan, sounds bogus to me ^
Ms2ger: it probably matched the spec when i wrote it
now it should set to null, right?
Right
wait, does testharness.js not have an equals() method that compares objects?
How would you compare them?
iterate over all keys/values in both objects and see if there’s a difference
would cover most cases
QUnit does it like this: https://github.com/jquery/qunit/blob/b0c3da8d09b1dcbe5dd0877e27386f4b9e8050a1/qunit/qunit.js#L1343-1525
matjas: Because there are a huge number of weird edge cases
e.g. loops in the object graph
and wanting to compare particular keys with something other than assert_equaks
*assert_equals
jgraham: why not add a simple method and document that it won’t work for every possible use case?
Because people will be surprised when it doesn't work for their use case
fair enough
And because it's hard to get right even in simple cases
and doesn't promote good quality tests (a single assert can only give a single error message)
(what was your use case?)
comparing fn.arguments with the arguments object in a function (it should be ===)
i just use assert_equals(argumentsProp === argumentsObject, true) now
but in other cases that wouldn’t be possible
But if they are === then assert_equals should work
assert_equals(argumentsProp, argumentsObject)
oh, right
do any of you know if this is a compatibility measure, or just a bug that all engines appear to have? https://mail.mozilla.org/pipermail/es-discuss/2012-July/023888.html
Heh, people still care about acid2
Ms2ger: var scrollTo = window.scrollTo; doesn't create a new variable binding
In the meantime, I found https://bugs.ecmascript.org/show_bug.cgi?id=78#c0
Ms2ger: I believe var self = 1; would mutate Window.prototype.self to equal 1.
(I could be wrong, I've never been that happy with this stuff)
That sounds rather unlikely
That's what I think.
Huh, how would that work?
But you get a reference for "scrollTo", which is a reference to Window.prototype.scrollTo, and then put a value on that reference.
Or am I being stupid?
that sounds rather likely :-P
Yes, it does. :P
No comment :)
Ms2ger: heh, that’s the link from http://mathias.html5.org/specs/javascript/#top-level-var-statements
matjas, <jorendorff> Ms2ger: if you look at ES5.1 �10.5, arguments object is created in steps 6-7; variables aren't bound until step 8
Ms2ger: cool, filed it here: Thanks for confirming. I filed it here: https://bugs.ecmascript.org/show_bug.cgi?id=440.
whoops copypasta
So the spec is correct, right?
Also...
A test!
Ms2ger: the spec text is wrong, but the steps are right
Oh, �10.6 disagrees with �10.5?
unless i misread the text
“an `arguments` object is created unless […] the identifier `arguments` occurs as […] the Identifier of a VariableDeclaration […] contained in the function code.” seems to conflict with 10.5
Looks like we all agree on that point :)
so in the case of function fn() { var arguments = undefined; return typeof arguments; }; fn(); // "undefined"
the `arguments` object is created in step 7
but then overwritten by the variable in step 8, iiuc
heh
I’m now passing Acid2 :) http://weasyprint.org/#acid2
SimonSapin: nice work
matjas: thanks
We’re a bit late to the party but we only started 14 months ago
matjas, no, it's not overwritten due to 8.c
Ms2ger: oic. but how is `var arguments;` different from `var arguments = undefined;`, then?
aren’t both VariableDeclarations?
`var arguments = undefined;` is `var arguments; argument = undefined;`
<jorendorff>       function fn() { alert(typeof arguments); var arguments = undefined;  alert(typeof arguments); }
<jorendorff> alerts "object" then "undefined"
<jorendorff> All the steps in 10.5 happen before the function body starts running.
Is anyone else doing proxies, btw?
awaits an xkcd about higgs
Ms2ger: Not yet afaik
zcorpan: me too, I wonder if it'll be about the font :)
Ms2ger: thanks! http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-12.2 VariableDeclaration : Identifier vs. VariableDeclaration : Identifier Initialiser
i guess i was thrown off by this: function fn() { alert(typeof arguments); var arguments; alert(typeof arguments); }; fn(); // alerts "object" twice
That's consistent with what I said, I think :)
sure, it all makes sense in YOUR head!
:D
Ms2ger: http://ecma-international.org/ecma-262/5.1/#sec-12.2 says “Variables are initialised to `undefined` when created” — so I expected `var foo;` to set it to undefined upon creation
But 8.c means there's no variable
…as varAlreadyDeclared is false, because the `arguments` object is already created at that point
so only when you do `[var] arguments = undefined` it overwrites that
FINALLY
I don’t know why I keep trying to read specs… not even all this Higgs boson talk makes me feel this stupid :)
/s/false/true/ a couple of messages back
ES is horrible, I can only do this thanks to a smart guy in another channel :)
ES is just quite complicated
the spec is a bit weirder than other specs, too
I'm not sure that any other programming language spec would be simpler
e.g. “If experValue is null or undefined, return (normal, empty, empty).” — what the hell is (normal, empty, empty)?
That's defined elsewhere
undoubtedly. but in WHATWG/W3C specs you’d get a clickable link to the explanation/definition
stuff like that helps make things a bit more n00b-friendly
http://es5.github.com/#x8.9
although i can see how that is not the goal of any spec
One major problem with ECMAScript is that it doesn't use HTML natively so obvious features like hypoerlinks of definitions are missing
e.g. if that was phrased If experValue is null or undefined, return the [completion type] (normal, empty, empty).", with the bit in square brackets being a link it would be a lot easier to work with
jgraham: exactly
♥ Anolis
matjas: We love you too.
Ms2ger: ask jorendorff to accept https://github.com/jorendorff/es-spec-html/pull/8 please
wants to delete fork

including something like krijn's logs
